metadata.case_name: Zamindars of Hemgir and Sarpgarh v. State of Orissa

facts.text: Two Zamindars of Hemgir and Sarpgarh moved Orissa High Court under Art. 226 for writ of mandamus against State of Orissa and Collector of Sundargarh challenging constitutionality of Orissa Estates Abolition Amendment Act (Orissa XVII of 1954).
Zamindaries comprised about 540 sq. miles between them, including considerable forest areas which had no separate existence in law.

Remote ancestors of petitioners were Bhuiyan Chiefs who became chieftains exercising sovereign powers; later accepted suzerainty of Rajput Rulers of Gangpur and surrendered sovereign rights; paid annual Takolis originally as tribute, later indistinguishable from land revenue.
In successive revenue settlements by Ruler of Gangpur with concurrence of Political Department of Government of India, they were described as Zamindars and Khewats issued.

High Court found Zamindars lost all vestiges of sovereignty, became subject to laws of Ruler of Gangpur; on merger of Gangpur with Orissa effective January 1, 1948, they were mere subjects with no claims to sovereign power.
Orissa Estates Abolition Act 1 of 1952 enacted and came into force February 1952; Government notified petitioners' properties under it.

Appellants with Nagra proprietor challenged 1952 Act in High Court; majority held Act valid but Supreme Court in Biswambhar Singh v. State of Orissa allowed appeals of Hemgir and Sarpgarh as not intermediaries under s.2(h); distinguished Nagra.
Orissa Legislature passed Amending Act XVII of 1954 recasting definitions of 'estate' (s.2(g)) and 'intermediary' (s.2(h)) to overcome Supreme Court decision.

High Court dismissed petitions on April 25, 1957, holding lands were estates under Art.31A(2)(a), Act not discriminatory under Art.14, not void under Art.254(1), UDHR Art.17(2) not justiciable; parties bear own costs.
Certificates of fitness granted by High Court for appeal to Supreme Court.
Laws of Gangpur State applied in Hemgir and Sarpgarh by own force; administration by staff of Ruler of Gangpur.
Sundargarh district formed after merger of feudatory State of Gangpur.

legal_issues.text: Constitutionality of Orissa Estates Abolition Amendment Act (Orissa XVII of 1954) and whether lands of Hemgir and Sarpgarh Zamindars constitute 'estates' held by 'intermediaries' under amended ss.2(g) and 2(h).
Whether appellants held sovereign status such that their lands could not be acquired under the Act, and whether Takoli paid was tribute or land revenue.
Whether Act discriminatory under Art.14, void under Art.254(1), or violates Art.17(2) UDHR.

petitioner_arguments.text: Even after amendment, legislature failed to bring lands within Act; appellants were sovereign rulers whose States could not be taken over.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Amended ss.2(g), 2(h) Orissa Estates Abolition Act 1952

petitioner_arguments.text: Definition of intermediary in amended s.2(h) does not cover their properties; they were sovereigns, Takoli was tribute not land revenue; no act of State by conquest, treaty or cession.
Lands not estates as defined in Art.31A(2)(a); Act discriminatory; violates Art.14, Art.254(1); violates Art.17(2) UDHR.

respondent_arguments.text: Appellants lost sovereignty through historical process, became Zamindars subject to Gangpur laws; lands are estates and they are intermediaries under amended definitions; Takoli is land revenue.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Amended ss.2(g), 2(h) Orissa Estates Abolition Act 1952; Explanations I-III to s.2(g)

court_reasoning.text: Agrees with High Court that appellants lost all vestiges of sovereignty by historical process; by 1948 merger, mere subjects; no sovereign powers left as Gangpur laws applied by own force and administration controlled by Gangpur Ruler.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sovereign powers acquired by historical process without merger of territory; no vestige of sovereignty by 1947.

court_reasoning.text: Amended s.2(h) all-inclusive definition covers appellants as holders of interest in land between raiyat and State; not raiyats; Takoli is land revenue per Explanation I and III to s.2(g).
court_reasoning.key_observation: No tertium quid between sovereign State and subject; appellants became subjects of Gangpur Ruler.

court_reasoning.text: Act not discriminatory (Art.14); not void (Art.254(1)); UDHR not justiciable.

holdings.text: Appellants are intermediaries under s.2(h) and lands are estates under s.2(g); liable to acquisition under Act.
No sovereign status remained; historical process vested sovereignty in Gangpur Ruler.

precedents_cited.case_name: Biswambhar Singh v. State of Orissa
precedents_cited.relevance: Prior decision holding Hemgir and Sarpgarh not intermediaries under original Act, prompting amendment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Promod Chandra Deb v. State of Orissa
precedents_cited.relevance: Act of State may result from historical process, not just conquest or treaty.

precedents_cited.case_name: Thakur Amar Singhji v. State of Rajasthan
precedents_cited.relevance: Position analogous to Bhomicharas of Rajasthan.

precedents_cited.case_name: Amarsarjit Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Position analogous to Cis-Sutlej jagirdars in Punjab.

statutes_cited.name: Orissa Estates Abolition Act, 1952 (Orissa 1 of 1952)
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines 'estate' and 'intermediary'; amended to include appellants' lands.

statutes_cited.name: Orissa Estates Abolition Amendment Act, 1954 (Orissa XVII of 1954)
statutes_cited.relevance: Recasts definitions of estate and intermediary to overcome prior Supreme Court ruling.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for High Court petitions; Act upheld against challenges.

outcome.summary: Appeals dismissed as without merit; lands of Hemgir and Sarpgarh Zamindars held liable to acquisition under Orissa Estates Abolition Act as amended.

key_quotes.text: The law does not know any tertium quid between a sovereign State and a State which is partly sovereign and partly not so.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects intermediate sovereign status; appellants fully subjects.

key_quotes.text: If the interest of these appellants is not that of a sovereign State, they hold their property as intermediaries and the payment which they used to make to the Raja of Gangpur, and later to the State of Orissa, would be in the nature of land revenue.
key_quotes.speaker: court
